public class NAME_ME_Player

This is where you'll write your code for this project. Be sure to rename the class to something unique just for your team.

Constructor Detail

NAME_ME_Player

public NAME_ME_Player()
Create a NAME_ME_Player object. Note that setSymbol and setTime must be called before the object can be used. This is done in the Game constructor.

Method Detail

eval

protected int eval(State currState)
Returns an evaluation of the given state from the perspective of playerSymbol (inherited from PlayerDef).
A positive score is good for this player - the higher the better. A negative score is bad for this player - the lower the worse. Always return a score from the perspective of *this* player (playerSymbol), even in the midst of the minimax algorithm.

Make sure evalState is zero-sum. That is, if this player evaluates a state as 65, then the other player using the same evaluation function would evaluate it to -65.

expand

protected ArrayList<State> expand(State currState,
                                  char symbol)
Returns an ArrayList of State objects, representing the children of the given state. An ArrayList is used here, in case the constant-time indexing is valuable to you in your work. I recommend using the index in the ArrayList as the column ID. For example, the state resulting from a move in column 0 should be in index 0 of the ArrayList, etc. If a column is full, use a null placeholder in that spot in the ArrayList.

Parameters:
currState - the state to expand
symbol - the symbol of the player that is about to move. Note that this is not necessarily the same as the playerSymbol field inherited from PlayerDef!

getMove

public int getMove(State currState,
                   int timeLeft)
Ultimately, this will be minimax with alpha-beta pruning, but get plain old minimax working first, and save a copy of it in case you mess something up while working on alpha-beta pruning.

Specified by:
getMove in class PlayerDef
Returns:
the column of the desired move
